Almost none of these things are surprising in their potential to catch fire and burn and have been known about for decades and some, even centuries for this potential. Chemistry and physics had some of these figured out in the middle to late 18th century and the massive Western industrial revolution in the 19th century expanded the knowledge of how and why through the unfortunate accidents from large devastating explosions and fires. Folk wisdom from years long observation and experience played a major role pre industrial revolution laying the ground work for the science of how and why common things can be flammable. Other fun celluloid sources: eyeglasses, some guitar pickguards (especially the nicer tortoise shell look and some pearloids), and fountain pens (especially vintage ones). Most modern celluloid is cellulose acetate, though, rather than nitrocellulose, and is more stable and less flammable. Nitrocellulose is still used as a guitar finish on higher end guitars (as, frankly, it shows off the wood far better), especially those sold as reliced guitars, e.g., Fender's Vintera Road Worn series. These days, nitrocellulose is typically only used for solid colors on guitars due to it being many layers of a super thin finish (and shimmers and glitters not being thin enough so taking many extra coats to cover, thus a waste of an expensive finish when urethane is a better choice). Also, weren't billiard balls nitrocellulose at some point? I recall an old James Burke Connections bit about that.

There is one conceptual thermodynamics correction needed on the video. The energy that comes from burning starch does not come from the breaking of the bonds between Hydrogen and Carbon, but by the making of bonds between those and Oxygen. So starch has a lot of chemical energy potential when exposed to a highly oxidizing atmosphere, mostly due to the new bonds that may be made, and not by the breaking of the present in it.

Objects made from pure (or near-pure) magnesium metal, such as some pencil sharpeners and certain parts of cars and bicycles, can ignite with an extremely
bright and very hot flame when heated for enough time by a blowtorch. The effect is more dramatic if you reduce the particle size by grinding the magnesium down to shavings, granules or a powder. The smaller the particle size, the faster the exothermic reaction with atmospheric oxygen. Magnesium-aluminium alloys (magnalium) also can be used. See the video by channel: Beyond the Press: "Magnesium powder explosion. The brightest thing you have ever seen". (footnote: if you wish to try this experiment yourself, please do it safely and with mindfulness, thought and planning!).

I almost used Tru oil to put a thin finish on a telecaster neck last year, probably still will on another project in the future. Anyways I just thought it was cool the video mentioned linseed oil. Also Celluloid is the most common guitar pick and pickguard material (or at least it was until the last couple decades) and it's so flammable that you cant import or export it anymore.

Many dust based industries have fire hazards, I worked in a metal grinding plant that produced powdered metal for various purposes. The mill had an explosively vented roof, so when the mill exploded (not if, when), the explosion would be “harmlessly” vented away. Fun fact: If you cut up a ping pong ball into small pieces, place them on an aluminium foil sheet, hold a pen upright in the centre, and wrap it so the foil contains the ping pong pieces, and wraps around the pen, leaving a hole at the top. Just make sure you do it outside, away from people, and don't breathe in the smoke.

Oxygenation is named after oxygen, but there are less common elements that also have the same effect.
The famous one of these being fluorine, which is a much stronger oxidizer than oxygen itself. Which means that it can remove the oxygen from things that have already burned to take it's place instead. Fluorine can burn ash, rock, and concrete. In addition to everything else that can burn with oxygen.

Thanks to Mythbusters and highschool chemistry class I knew about all of these.

Here are some more examples:

- Dryer lint (countless drying fires are caused every year by neglecting to empty out the lint trap.)
- Used 9-volt batteries (if thrown in the trash alongside combustible refuse residual sparks can cause trash fires.)
- Lysol and other air fresheners. (There's a reason they're often used as makeshift flamethrowers in action movies.)
- Styrofoam. (Same reason as ping-pong balls.)
- Aluminum + iron rust (if given a spark, this can cause a self-oxidizing reaction that burns hot enough to melt through almost any material. It was one of the Mythbuster's favourite crazy things to work with for this reason. They used it to literally melt a car in half.)

Even before being ground into flour, grain silos are also at risk of exploding, because dust from the grain will ignite just like flour!

Minneapolis was known as “Mill City”, one of the larger flour mills was the Washburn A Mill which opened its doors to begin processing flour in 1874. But in May 1878, just four years after opening, a spark ignited airborne flour dust, creating an explosion that claimed 18 lives, leveled the mill, and destroyed much of the riverfront business area. Minneapolis’s milling capacity was cut in half. Next time you do a video, do more research and show some respect.

My top 5 flammable household items,
1 and 2 powder coffee creamer, and flour, both are highly flammable when turned into airborne dust particles.

margarine/butter

Fun fact: "Keep your nose to the grindstone" comes from flour mills. When you were working fast, you had to keep your nose next to the grindstone to smell if the flour was getting too hot. My wife one night while I was taking a nap, she screwed up and it was bad. One of my kids had spilt some grease moving a skillet. I woke up to the smoke alarm going off and as I was walking into the kitchen, my wife had a 5lb bag of flour and was in the motion of throwing it on the fire. I saw what she had and started screaming NOOO!!! But it is so hard to stop when you already started. I think we are all like that. The flower was like an explosion of fire and luckily I had a fire extinguisher next to the fridge. So I was able to put it out almost as fast as it started.
I asked her what in the world was she doing? She said that the fire chief that lives next door had said the easiest way of putting a grease fire out. Is by a simple stuff that you have at the house already. She says that she remembers him saying flour!!! I told her, yes baby you probably did hear him say flour. She says you see even you agree. I said yeah I agree that he said NEVER USE FLOUR TO PUT A FIRE OUT!!! At 11pm she walked next door and woke that old man up to ask him about flour on a grease fire.... I was so embarrassed and trying so hard to apologize to him for her waking him up. She told him that she was not able to sleep until she knew that either she was right or if I was right. The fire chief just said, yeah never use flour to put any kind of fire out especially a grease fire. Flour becomes a fuel that will burn your house down before you can make a call or do anything. She asked him, what did you tell us to use then. He said Baking soda young lady baking soda. I just said thank you and turned to my wife and said, baby can we please go to bed now. Damp hay/straw can catch on fire on its own. If you gather/bale it without it being dry enough, microorganisms will start breaking it down. The heat from this process is enough to make it catch on fire if it is stored semi-compactly. A lot of barns and haystacks have burned down due to this.

Great video! Something I wanted to point out  is that fire requires 4 things, not 3, to happen. Oxygen, heat, fuel, and the chemical reaction. That's why we use a fire tetrahedron rather than a fire triangle these days when describing ways to extinguish fires. There are fire extinguishers that specifically disrupt the chemical reaction in order to put out fires, instead of trying to reduce heat or cut off oxygen like with water or CO2 respectively.

Ok. Linseed oil itself does not do this. If you buy food grade linseed oil it cannot catch things on fire "spontaneously". This only happens with linseed oil design for art, furniture, etc. this is because the linseed oil is mixed with other materials (many of them are toxic) that allow the oil to dry and become solid. People are confused because linseed oil not intended for human consumption doesn't require a proper ingredient label.

Linseed oil does not dry it cures. Drying is a process by which material loses its moisture content, where as curing is a process that involves chemistry of an object to produce some other secondary chemical and the final product.
